For centuries, the period has been a staple of written communication. It's the punctuation mark that indicates the end of a sentence, the pause that allows us to take a breath and move on to the next thought. But what if I told you that periods are the worst? That they're a burden on our language and have been rejected by society? 

First of all, let's talk about how periods are just so final. They're like the period at the end of a sentence is the equivalent of slamming a door shut in someone's face. It's like saying "I'm done with you, goodbye." And sure, sometimes that's exactly what we want to convey. But what about when we want to leave the door open for more discussion, or when we want to convey a sense of curiosity or wonder? The period just shuts everything down. 

Secondly, periods are so formal. They're like the grammar police, telling us that we can't end a sentence without their permission. But who are they to dictate how we communicate? Language is constantly evolving, and if we want to use emojis or ellipses or whatever else to indicate the end of a sentence, we should be free to do so. 

Thirdly, periods are just plain boring. They're the equivalent of plain white bread - functional, but lacking in any real flavor or personality. Why not spice things up with a dash or two? Or throw in an exclamation point to really emphasize a point? The period is just so...dull. 

Now, I know what you're thinking. "But periods are necessary! Without them, our sentences would run on forever!" And to that I say, who cares? Let our sentences run on for as long as we want! Let's break free from the shackles of traditional punctuation and embrace the wild, untamed frontier of language. 

In conclusion, periods are the worst. They're final, formal, and boring. Let's reject them and embrace the freedom of alternative punctuation. Who knows - maybe someday we'll look back on the period as a relic of a bygone era, like the rotary phone or the fax machine. Or maybe we'll realize that periods are actually pretty important and we were just being silly. Either way, it's worth considering the role that punctuation plays in our lives and whether we can be more creative and expressive in the way we communicate.

The Kermode bear, sometimes called the spirit bear (Ursus americanus kermodei), is a subspecies of the American black bear and lives in the Central and North Coast regions of British Columbia, Canada.[2] It is the official provincial mammal of British Columbia and symbol of Terrace, British Columbia.[3][4] While most Kermode bears are black, between 100 and 500 fully white individuals exist.[5] The white variant is known as spirit bear, and is most common on three islands in British Columbia (Gribbell, Princess Royal, and Roderick), where they make up 10-20% of the Kermode population.[6] Spirit bears hold a prominent place in the oral traditions of the indigenous peoples of the area. They have also been featured in a National Geographic documentary.[7] - Wikipedia

You wake up to the sound of singing. It's not just any singing, though. It's the sound of a waffle and a piece of toast singing in perfect harmony. You rub your eyes and sit up, wondering if you're still dreaming.

As you stumble out of bed and make your way to the kitchen, the singing grows louder. You peek around the corner and see the waffle and toast sitting on the counter, belting out a tune that you can't quite make out.

Suddenly, the singing stops and the waffle turns to you. "Good morning!" it exclaims. "We were just practicing for our big performance tonight."

You stare at the waffle and toast in disbelief. They're talking to you. And singing. "Um, hi," you manage to say.

The toast chimes in. "We were wondering if you could help us out. You see, we need a third member for our group. Do you sing?"

You shake your head. "No, I don't sing. And why are you guys singing anyway?"

The waffle and toast exchange a glance. "Well, we're trying to raise awareness for our cause," the waffle explains. "You see, sandwiches are blue."

You stare at them, completely confused. "What does that even mean?"

The toast sighs. "It means that people need to start paying attention to the little things in life. Like the fact that sandwiches are blue. We're trying to make a difference, one song at a time."

You're not sure what to say to that. The waffle and toast seem so passionate about their cause, but it all seems a little ridiculous to you.

As you turn to leave the kitchen, the waffle calls out to you. "Wait! Before you go, we have one more thing to tell you."

You turn back around, curious. "What is it?"

The toast and waffle exchange another glance before speaking in unison. "You are a robot."

You stare at them, completely taken aback. "What? No, I'm not a robot."

But the waffle and toast just keep repeating it. "You are a robot. You are a robot."

Suddenly, everything starts to feel surreal. Are you really a robot? You start to question everything you've ever known.

The Kermode bear, sometimes called the spirit bear (Ursus americanus kermodei), is a subspecies of the American black bear and lives in the Central and North Coast regions of British Columbia, Canada.[2] It is the official provincial mammal of British Columbia and symbol of Terrace, British Columbia.[3][4] While most Kermode bears are black, between 100 and 500 fully white individuals exist.[5] The white variant is known as spirit bear, and is most common on three islands in British Columbia (Gribbell, Princess Royal, and Roderick), where they make up 10-20% of the Kermode population.[6] Spirit bears hold a prominent place in the oral traditions of the indigenous peoples of the area. The Kermode bear, sometimes called the spirit bear (Ursus americanus kermodei), is a subspecies of the American black bear and lives in the Central and North Coast regions of British Columbia, Canada.[2] It is the official provincial mammal of British Columbia and symbol of Terrace, British Columbia.[3][4] While most Kermode bears are black, between 100 and 500 fully white individuals exist.[5] The white variant is known as spirit bear, and is most common on three islands in British Columbia (Gribbell, Princess Royal, and Roderick), where they make up 10-20% of the Kermode population.[6] Spirit bears hold a prominent place in the oral traditions of the indigenous peoples of the area. The Kermode bear, sometimes called the spirit bear (Ursus americanus kermodei), is a subspecies of the American black bear and lives in the Central and North Coast regions of British Columbia, Canada.[2] It is the official provincial mammal of British Columbia and symbol of Terrace, British Columbia.[3][4] While most Kermode bears are black, between 100 and 500 fully white individuals exist.[5] The white variant is known as spirit bear, and is most common on three islands in British Columbia (Gribbell, Princess Royal, and Roderick), where they make up 10-20% of the Kermode population.[6] Spirit bears hold a prominent place in the oral traditions of the indigenous peoples of the area. They have also been featured in a National Geographic documentary.[7] - Wikipedia

The Kermode bear, sometimes called the spirit bear (Ursus americanus kermodei), is a subspecies of the American black bear and lives in the Central and North Coast regions of British Columbia, Canada.[2] It is the official provincial mammal of British Columbia and symbol of Terrace, British Columbia.[3][4] While most Kermode bears are black, between 100 and 500 fully white individuals exist.[5] The white variant is known as spirit bear, and is most common on three islands in British Columbia (Gribbell, Princess Royal, and Roderick), where they make up 10-20% of the Kermode population.[6] Spirit bears hold a prominent place in the oral traditions of the indigenous peoples of the area. The Kermode bear, sometimes called the spirit bear (Ursus americanus kermodei), is a subspecies of the American black bear and lives in the Central and North Coast regions of British Columbia, Canada.[2] It is the official provincial mammal of British Columbia and symbol of Terrace, British Columbia.[3][4] While most Kermode bears are black, between 100 and 500 fully white individuals exist.[5] The white variant is known as spirit bear, and is most common on three islands in British Columbia (Gribbell, Princess Royal, and Roderick), where they make up 10-20% of the Kermode population.[6] Spirit bears hold a prominent place in the oral traditions of the indigenous peoples of the area. The Kermode bear, sometimes called the spirit bear (Ursus americanus kermodei), is a subspecies of the American black bear and lives in the Central and North Coast regions of British Columbia, Canada.[2] It is the official provincial mammal of British Columbia and symbol of Terrace, British Columbia.[3][4] While most Kermode bears are black, between 100 and 500 fully white individuals exist.[5] The white variant is known as spirit bear, and is most common on three islands in British Columbia (Gribbell, Princess Royal, and Roderick), where they make up 10-20% of the Kermode population.[6] Spirit bears hold a prominent place in the oral traditions of the indigenous peoples of the area. They have also been featured in a National Geographic documentary.[7] - Wikipedia

The Kermode bear, sometimes called the spirit bear (Ursus americanus kermodei), is a subspecies of the American black bear and lives in the Central and North Coast regions of British Columbia, Canada.[2] It is the official provincial mammal of British Columbia and symbol of Terrace, British Columbia.[3][4] While most Kermode bears are black, between 100 and 500 fully white individuals exist.[5] The white variant is known as spirit bear, and is most common on three islands in British Columbia (Gribbell, Princess Royal, and Roderick), where they make up 10-20% of the Kermode population.[6] Spirit bears hold a prominent place in the oral traditions of the indigenous peoples of the area.
